intro: Rhynchospora fauriei var. leviseta, commonly known as the broad-leaved marsh sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland habitats in the southeastern United States. It typically grows in moist to wet soils, often found in marshes, swales, and along the edges of ponds. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves that are usually broader than those of other sedge species, and it produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters. Its inflorescence consists of a dense spike of green to reddish-brown spikelets, which are characteristic of the Cyperaceae family. Rhynchospora fauriei var. leviseta plays a role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
